definitions.definition: An assimilatory process whereby a vowel is pronounced more like a following vocoid that is separated by one or more consonants .

The umlaut process (as above) that occurred historically in Germanic languages whereby back vowels became front vowels when followed by syllable containing a front vocoid (e.g. Germanic lūsiz > Old English lȳs(i) > Modern English lice ).
The diacritical mark ( ¨ ) placed over a vowel when it indicates a ( rounded ) front vowel

examples: "Naïve" takes an umlaut because it is pronounced as two syllables.

main_definition: ( linguistics ) An assimilatory process whereby a vowel is pronounced more like a following vocoid that is separated by one or more consonants .
secondary_definitions: ( linguistics ) The umlaut process (as above) that occurred historically in Germanic languages whereby back vowels became front vowels when followed by syllable containing a front vocoid (e.g. Germanic lūsiz > Old English lȳs(i) > Modern English lice ).
( orthography ) The diacritical mark ( ¨ ) placed over a vowel when it indicates a ( rounded ) front vowel
